TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit XmlFormView extends System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart implements class System.Web.UI.INamingContainer

Docs.summary: The main ASP.NET control used to show InfoPath forms in a browser.

remarks.para: The object and its associated members are used to display InfoPath forms in a Web browser. No additional components are necessary on the desktop computer except a Web browser in order to open and fill out a form based on a browser-enabled form template.

InfoPath Forms Services uses the control to display forms based on form templates designed in Microsoft InfoPath so that they are browser-compatible. Developers can also use the control to show InfoPath forms in custom Web pages. This requires Microsoft SharePoint Server 2010 with a client access license for InfoPath Forms Services. For more information on how to develop custom Web pages with the control, see Hosting the InfoPath Form Editing Environment in a Custom Web Form.
Note: As an alternative to using the control, you can now use the to display InfoPath forms in SharePoint pages. For more information, see Working with the InfoPath Form Web Part.

example.para: In the following example, the control, XmlFormView1, is hosted in a custom Web page and contains a browser-enabled form template located on the same site. The event of the control is used to populate a control, TextBox1, in the custom Web page.
example.code: Imports Microsoft.Office.InfoPath.Server.Controls Protected Sub XmlFormView1_NotifyHost(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As Microsoft.Office.InfoPath.Server.Controls.NotifyHostEventArgs) Handles XmlFormView1.NotifyHost TextBox1.Text = e.Notification.ToString() End Sub
example.para: The form code necessary to send a value from the main data source in the form, my:field2, to the hosting Web page uses the method of the object available in the namespace, in this case from a button in the form.
example.code: Public Sub CTRL3_5_Clicked(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As ClickedEventArgs) Dim myNav As XPathNavigator = Me.MainDataSource.CreateNavigator() Me.NotifyHost(myNav.SelectSingleNode("/my:myFields/my:field2", Me.NamespaceManager).ToString()) End Sub
example.para: The form code necessary to send a value from the main data source in the form, my:field2, to the hosting Web page uses the method of the object available in the namespace, in this case from a button in the form.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor() cil managed

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

MemberSignature.Value: Public Custom Event Close As EventHandler

Docs.summary: Handles the close event of a form in a control.

remarks.para: This event represents one of four events of the control that allow communication of a form in the control to the Web page in which the control is hosted. Read-only properties of the form can be queried before the form is closed. These properties are available through the property of the control.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property Uri ^ DataConnectionBaseUrl { Uri ^ get(); void set(Uri ^ value); };

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the base URL that will replace the specified substring of the service URL for all relative Web services in the form.
Docs.value: The base URL that will replace the specified substring of the service URL for all relative Web services in the form.

remarks.para: Form templates containing Web service data connections can be modified to enable relative Web service URLs in place of the absolute Web service URLs used when the data connection is established in design mode. It requires modification of the manifest.xsf file of the form template in order to replace the xsf2:connectoid element with the xsf2:relativeQuery element, as in the example below. The replace attribute specifies the substring of the URL to replace at form initialization with the value set by the property.
Notes

item.description: If the relativeQuery element does not exist in the manifest extension for the adapter, the full serviceURL specified in the manifest will be used.
If is a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic) or , the full serviceURL specified in the manifest will be used.
The must be a valid URL.
An error will occur if the webServiceAdapterExt element contains both the xsf2:connectoid and the xsf2:relativeQuery elements.
The property applies to all Web service data connections in the form.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::String ^ DefaultView { System::String ^ get(); void set(System::String ^ value); };

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the default view for the form displayed in the control.
Docs.value: The name of the default view.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig virtual instance void Dispose() cil managed

Docs.summary: Enables the control to perform final clean up before it is released from memory.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property Microsoft::Office::InfoPath::Server::Controls::XmlFormView::EditingState EditingStatus { Microsoft::Office::InfoPath::Server::Controls::XmlFormView::EditingState get(); void set(Microsoft::Office::InfoPath::Server::Controls::XmlFormView::EditingState value); };

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the editing status of a form hosted in the control.

remarks.para: The property is based on the enumeration, which includes the following values.

item.description: The form is not visible when the Web page is opened. The must be changed to Editing before the form can be used.
The form is visible to the user and is ready to use.
The form is closed. The message "The form has been closed" is shown to the user inside the control.

MemberSignature.Value: Public Custom Event Initialize As EventHandler(Of InitializeEventArgs)

Docs.summary: Handles the initialization event of a form in a control.

remarks.para: This event represents one of four events of the control that allows communication of a form in the control to the Web page in which the control is hosted. Read-only properties of the form can be queried after the form is opened but before it is shown in the control. These properties are available through the property of the control.

example.para: In the following example, the property of the form is shown in a text box located on the Web page.
example.code: Protected Sub XmlFormView1_Initialize(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As Microsoft.Office.InfoPath.Server.Controls.InitializeEventArgs) Handles XmlFormView1.Initialize TextBox11.Text = XmlFormView1.EditingStatus.ToString() End Sub

MemberSignature.Value: Public Custom Event NotifyHost As EventHandler(Of NotifyHostEventArgs)

Docs.summary: Handles the host notification event of a form in an control.

remarks.para: This event represents one of four events of the control that allows communication of a form in the control to the Web page in which the control is hosted. Read-only properties of the form can be queried when code in the form is used to notify the hosting Web page. These properties are available through the property of the control.

example.para: In the following example, the control, XmlFormView1, is hosted in a custom Web page and contains a browser-enabled form template located on the same site. The event of the control is used to populate a control, TextBox1, in the custom Web page.
example.code: Imports Microsoft.Office.InfoPath.Server.Controls Protected Sub XmlFormView1_NotifyHost(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As Microsoft.Office.InfoPath.Server.Controls.NotifyHostEventArgs) Handles XmlFormView1.NotifyHost TextBox1.Text = e.Notification.ToString() End Sub
example.para: The form code necessary to send a value from the main data source in the form, my:field2, to the hosting Web page uses the method of the object available in the namespace, in this case from a button in the form.
example.code: Public Sub CTRL3_5_Clicked(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As ClickedEventArgs) Dim myNav As XPathNavigator = Me.MainDataSource.CreateNavigator() Me.NotifyHost(myNav.SelectSingleNode("/my:myFields/my:field2", Me.NamespaceManager).ToString()) End Sub
example.para: The form code necessary to send a value from the main data source in the form, my:field2, to the hosting Web page uses the method of the object available in the namespace, in this case from a button in the form.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::String ^ Options { System::String ^ get(); void set(System::String ^ value); };

Docs.summary: Gets or sets an option, namely , for the control.
Docs.value: , if the Save button has been disabled; otherwise .

remarks.para: The only supported value for the property is , which hides the Save button in the browser and disables the save feature of the form. The value is case-insensitive.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property bool PrintWindow { bool get(); void set(bool value); };

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the boolean value that controls whether the print view is shown.
Docs.value: true, if the print view is shown; otherwise, false.

remarks.para: If the form template loaded in the control does not contain a view designed for printing, the default view is shown and all data-bound controls are read-only and other controls, such as buttons, are hidden.

example.para: In the following example, the property of the control is set to true during the event.
example.code: Protected Sub XmlFormView1_Initialize(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As Microsoft.Office.InfoPath.Server.Controls.InitializeEventArgs) Handles XmlFormView1.Initialize XmlFormView1.PrintWindow = True End Sub

Docs.summary: This member is reserved for internal use and is not intended to be used directly from your code.

remarks.para: This member is not intended to be used directly from your code. This member is public because of Microsoft ASP.NET infrastructure requirements.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::String ^ SaveLocation { System::String ^ get(); void set(System::String ^ value); };

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the location to which the form will be saved.
Docs.value: The path to the save location.

remarks.para: When saving the form is disabled, the value of the property is ignored. When the property includes , the Save button will be hidden in the browser.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property bool ShowFooter { bool get(); void set(bool value); };

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the boolean value indicating whether the footer will be displayed below the form.
Docs.value: true, if the footer is displayed; otherwise, false.

remarks.para: The header and footer show common actions that can be taken by the user of the form, such as saving, printing, and switching views.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property bool ShowHeader { bool get(); void set(bool value); };

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the boolean value indicating whether the header will be displayed above the form.
Docs.value: true, if the header is displayed; otherwise, false.

remarks.para: The header and footer show common actions that can be taken by the user of the form, such as saving, printing, and switching views.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property SubmitStatus As XmlFormView.SubmitState

Docs.summary: Gets the state of last submit operation.

remarks.para: The property is based on the enumeration, which includes the following values.

item.description: The submit process encountered an error.
The form has not been submitted.
The most recent form submission was successful.

MemberSignature.Value: Public Custom Event SubmitToHost As EventHandler(Of SubmitToHostEventArgs)

Docs.summary: Handles the submit to host event of a form in a control.

remarks.para: This event represents one of four events of the control that allows communication of a form in the control to the Web page in which the control is hosted. Read-only properties of the form can be queried when the form is submitted to the hosting Web page. These properties are available through the property of the control.

example.para: In the following example, the property of the object is displayed in a text box located on the Web page.
example.code: Protected Sub XmlFormView1_SubmitToHost(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As Microsoft.Office.InfoPath.Server.Controls.SubmitToHostEventArgs) Handles XmlFormView1.SubmitToHost TextBox11.Text = e.ReturnStatus.ToString() End Sub

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property XmlForm As XmlForm
public: property Microsoft::Office::InfoPath::XmlForm ^ XmlForm { Microsoft::Office::InfoPath::XmlForm ^ get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets a reference to an object represents the current form and provides access to the form's main data source.

remarks.para: Use the property to get a reference to an object that represents the form. A limited subset of members of the class can be accessed when using the control. For more information about these members, see the Help included with Visual Studio 2012.
Properties (Read Only)
Methods
Important: Using members other than this subset will result in the error "Calling this property or method from a hosting page is not supported."
Using the XmlForm Property
The property can only be accessed during one of the following events:

example.para: In the following example, a series of textboxes in the Web page are populated with values from the properties that can be used by accessing the property. A value from the main data source of the form is used as the value for TextBox10. This routine is called when code in the form calls the method of the object available in the namespace, in this case from a button in the form.
The following example requires the following three Imports statements:
example.code: Imports System.Xml Imports System.Xml.XPath Imports Microsoft.Office.InfoPath.Server.Controls Protected Sub XmlFormView1_NotifyHost(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As Microsoft.Office.InfoPath.Server.Controls.NotifyHostEventArgs) Handles XmlFormView1.NotifyHost Dim xNavMain As XPathNavigator Dim xNameSpace As XmlNamespaceManager Try TextBox2.Text = XmlFormView1.XmlForm.[New].ToString() TextBox3.Text = XmlFormView1.XmlForm.ReadOnly.ToString() TextBox4.Text = XmlFormView1.XmlForm.MainDataSource.ReadOnly.ToString() TextBox5.Text = XmlFormView1.XmlForm.ToString() TextBox6.Text = XmlFormView1.XmlForm.XmlLang.ToString() TextBox7.Text = XmlFormView1.XmlForm.Signed.ToString() TextBox8.Text = XmlFormView1.XmlForm.FormState.Count.ToString() TextBox9.Text = XmlFormView1.XmlForm.DataSources.Count.ToString() xNavMain = XmlFormView1.XmlForm.MainDataSource.CreateNavigator() xNameSpace = New XmlNamespaceManager(New NameTable()) xNameSpace.AddNamespace("my", XmlFormView1.XmlForm.NamespaceManager._ LookupNamespace("my").ToString()) TextBox10.Text = xNavMain.SelectSingleNode("/my:myFields/my:field2", xNameSpace).ToString() Catch ex As Exception TextBox11.Text = ex.Message.ToString() End Try End Sub
example.para: The following example requires the following three using statements:

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::String ^ XmlLocation { System::String ^ get(); void set(System::String ^ value); };

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the URL of the form template's XML file.
Docs.value: The URL of the form template's XML file

remarks.para: This value can be set only when the of the form is not "Editing." Attempts to set the property when the form is currently being edited will result in an error.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::String ^ XsnLocation { System::String ^ get(); void set(System::String ^ value); };

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the URL that specifies the location of the form template.
Docs.value: A URL that specifies the location of the form template

remarks.para: This value can be set only when the of the form is not "Editing." Attempts to set the property when the form is currently being edited will result in an error.
